newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: SOCCER-ALGERIA RETURN TO FORM.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-ALGERIA RETURN TO FORM.

text.p: Algeria bounced back from World Cup disappointment with a convincing 4-1 victory over the Ivory Coast at the start of the 1998 African Nations' Cup qualifying campaign in Algiers on Sunday.

The one-sided victory -- one of 14 qualifying matches played on the contnent at the weekend -- came just months after the north Africans' shock elimination from the 1998 World Cup in the early qualifying round.

Their 3-2 aggregate defeat by Kenya in June led to the dissolution of the Algerian federation and a life ban on coaching in the country for Ali Fergani, a former World Cup hero who had taken Algeria to the 1996 Nations' Cup quarter-finals at the start of the year.
But a dominant performance in the group two match on Sunday, masterminded by acting coach Hamid Zouba, put Algerian soccer back on track.
Two goals each from captain Moussa Saib and striker Ali Messabih gave Algeria a confident start in their bid to qualify for the Nations' Cup finals in Burkina Faso in two years'time.
There were victories for several other heavily fancied contenders.

Ghana came back from conceding an early goal to Angola in group one in Accra on Sunday to triumph 2-1 with the winner scored by English-based striker Kim Grant. It was the first international goal in his third appearance for the Black Stars for Grant, who plays for first division Luton Town.

Zambia were also victors in their group seven encounter against Mozambique in Lusaka on Sunday but played a rear-guard action for most of the match after Kenneth Malitoli had given them a fourth-minute lead.
Egypt were held to a 1-1 draw by Morocco in group three in Cairo on Friday while Zaire also drew at home against disjointed Liberian team in Kinshasa on Sunday.

The Liberians, led by world footballer of the year George Weah, arrived in the central African country on the eve of the group six match without several of their home-based players, who finally turned up just hours before kick-off.
Liberia has been hit hard by an intermittent civil war and the team had to assemble in neighbouring Ivory Coast before heading south for the goalless match.
Zimbabwe, with controversial goalkeeper Bruce Grobbelaar as acting coach, beat Sudan 3-0 away in group one.
Malawi, Mali, Guinea and Senegal also scored valuable away wins.
